headline: Ruptured appendix could cause sudden death, infertility in women, physician warns
summarized_story:
Amarachi OkehA public health physician, Dr. Tunji Akintade has warned against delaying seeking medical intervention for appendicitis, noting that a ruptured appendix could cause sudden death and pelvic inflammatory disease which in turn could cause infertility in women.
“One of the complications of ruptured appendix is peritonitis which is the inflammation of the peritoneum.
According to, Medicalnewstoday – a medical news site, hydrosalpinx is the name for a condition in which a woman’s fallopian tube becomes blocked with fluid.
Continuing, Akintade said that ruptured appendicitis can also cause sepsis.
Speaking on how people may know their appendix has ruptured, the general practitioner said, “Once you have abdominal pain especially in the right area, you must see your doctor immediately.

headline: Nigeria, 3 others get £16.2m UK grant to fight plastic pollution

headline: I was chained legs, hands for 48hrs without food and water

headline: London: Nigerian High Commission shut over COVID-19 outbreak
summarized_story:
From Aidoghie Paulinus, AbujaThe Nigerian High Commission in London, United Kingdom, has been shut for 10 days after two officials tested positive to COVID-19.
The Nigerian High Commission in London, in a statement issued on Thursday, narrated that yesterday afternoon, the Head of Immigration Section and two other officials went for a meeting at the Home Office.
The mission further said at the entrance, COVID-19 test was administered on them and one of them tested positive to the virus.
The High Commission added that the affected officer immediately isolated, while the other officials, who tested negative will also isolate for the next 10 days.
“While the High Commission regrets any inconvenience that this may have caused, we solicit the cooperation of the general public,” the Nigerian High Commission in London said.

headline: Buhari returns from UK medical vacation
summarized_story:
President Muhammadu Buhari on Friday returned to Nigeria from London, United Kingdom, after undergoing medical checkup.

headline: SEC says Nigeria’s unclaimed dividends now N170bn
summarized_story:

According to him, the figure had increased compared with N158.44 billion total unclaimed dividends as of December 2019.

He noted that the commission constituted a Committee on Identity Management for the Nigerian Capital Market in June in order to address the unclaimed dividend issue.

headline: Okupe: Nigeria’s Political Parties Taking People for Granted, Performance Abysmally Poor
summarized_story:
As the tension continues to subside in Nigeria’s main opposition party, the Peoples Democratic Party all eyes ard now on the October Convention initially fixed for December.
With the latest development, embattled National Chairman of the party, Prince Uche Secondus, will no longer be forced to resign as being canvassed by some members of the National Executive Committee, National Working Committee, House of Representatives Caucus, youths and governors.
As rumoured, the October convention will most likely present a new Chairman for the party, who will come from the northern region of Nigeria.
This should pave the way for a southern region presidential zoning arrangement for the 2023 general election in Nigeria.
To discuss the political intrigues in PDP ahead of the 2023 elections, is Dr. Doyin Okupe, a Nigerian physician and politician, was on Friday’s Morning Show.

headline: Trending: Pastor Snatches Church Member’s Wife
summarized_story:
A Ghanaian clergywoman, Akua Ofori-Boateng, stunned the members of her church recently when she made them sing along to Nigerian singer, Teni The Entertainer’s song, Case.
In a video shared on her Instagram page, the clergywoman can be seen with her choristers singing and dancing to the song during their church service.
Meanwhile in Nigeria, another top Boko Haram Senior Commander Amir Adamu Rugu and his family surrendered to troops of operation Hadin Kai in Gwoza Local Government Area of Borno state.
Finally, reactions continue to trail the story of Pastor Moses Adeeyo who snatched and married the wife of his church member Tina Bright, now Tina Adeeyo.

headline: Vote Count Begins in Zambia’s Closely Fought Elections
summarized_story:
Electoral officials in Zambia has commenced vote counting following the successful staging of the southern African nation’s general elections.
Some voters complained about the slow pace of voting in an election that is seen as a test of Zambia’s democracy.
President Edgar Lungu deployed more troops in parts of the country to quell election violence in the tightly contested polls pitting him against long-time rival Hakainde Hichilema.
“How can you talk about free and fair elections when our opponents have taken this election as war?” he said.
Addressing opposition fears of fraud, Hichilema said Zambia’s next leader “must be determined by the… voters, not the people who count the votes”.

headline: South Africa Wants More Men to Take Covid Jabs
summarized_story:
South Africa has urged more men in the country to come out in larger numbers and take Covid jabs as their numbers trails that of women.
About 60% of vaccines have been administered to women, health officials noted on Friday during a media briefing on the government’s efforts in the fight against the disease.
Health Minister Joe Phaahla ruled out the easing of Covid restrictions despite a “downward trend” in infections.
South Africa has so far registered 2,568,511 cases of Covid and 76,243 deaths.
It has the most cases in Africa.

headline: Sudan, ICC Sign Cooperation Deal, as Darfur Trials Inch Closer
summarized_story:
Sudan has signed a cooperation deal with the International Criminal Court, a step further towards ex-dictator Omar al-Bashir facing trial for genocide in the Darfur conflict.
Bashir, 77, has been wanted by the ICC for more than a decade over charges of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity in the Sudanese region.
Two other former aides are also wanted to face war crimes charges.
The ICC issued an arrest warrant for Bashir in 2009 for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur, later adding genocide to the charges.
Bashir is jailed alongside two other former top officials facing ICC war crimes charges — ex-defence minister Abdel Rahim Mohamed Hussein and Ahmed Haroun, a former governor of South Kordofan.
